reface
In support of the International Conference on Indian Ocean Studies, being held at Perth, August
1979 during the 1 50th Anniversary Year of Western Australia, the National Library has compiled
a bibliography of its resources for the study of the Indian Ocean Region. This bibliography has
been compiled by staff from the National Library's three subject libraries, ANNUL, ANSOL and
ANSTEL, which cover the humanities, the social sciences, and science and technology. The
principal compilers were Graeme Powell, Gints Stipnieks, Toni Edvi-llles and Geraldine Triffitt.
The work was edited by Pauline Crawcour and Shirley Holt.
It is particularly appropriate that the Library's first extensive area studies bibliography has been
produced to coincide with the creation within the National Library of a fourth subject library the
Australian International and Ethnic Library (AUSINTEL) which will be issuing similar bibliog-
raphies and current awareness bulletins of its international holdings from time to time.
George Chandler
Director-General
National Library of Australia




Introduction
This bibliography on the Indian Ocean lists a selection of the National Library's large collections
both fully catalogued and partly catalogued on the Indian Ocean Region. Effort has been
concentrated on the Ocean itself, the islands of the Ocean and the littoral states in relation to the
Ocean, with passing reference only to their internal affairs. Works on the littoral states are listed
elsewhere in National Library publications such as Australian national bibliography, APAIS,
Acquisitions newsletter, Indonesian acquisitions list, Indian periodicals and newspapers.
Southeast Asian periodicals and official publications and Newspapers in Australian libraries: a
union list.
Language, literature and the arts, including films, and music, have been excluded in favour of
history, the social sciences and natural sciences. A detailed guide to the subject arrangement
under these broad headings is given as the contents list. The personal name index in the back of
the volume refers to entry numbers.
The bibliography lists over six thousand items including books, journal articles, government
publications, manuscripts, maps and pictorial materials some of which are held in microcopy
only. Material in non-Roman script and in Asian languages other than Indonesian has been
excluded. The 700 entries for maps are in Section 7 and are numbered in a separate sequence
from the rest of the bibliography. The personal name index reflects these two numbering
sequences.
The bibliography covers such diverse subjects as history, exploration, population movements,
missionary activities, international relations, law and defence, as well as oceanography,
meteorology, marine biology and geology. The entries are arranged alphabetically by author
within each subject area. The guide to the arrangement given in the contents list should be
consulted for access to these subjects. All entries give the National Library call number to make it
easier to consult the material in the Library itself and to speed up inter-library loans.
Entries were compiled with the help of existing bibliographies, periodical indexes, catalogues
and computer data bases. The collections were checked physically for retrospective material in
history and the social sciences. For ongoing research it should be pointed out that the National
Library has virtually complete documentary back-up for material quoted in current issues of
Science Citation Index and Social Science Citation Index.

5398 ABBOTT, J.H.M.
Manuscript, 1910
93 leaves
The records of the Council for World Mission (incor-
porating the archivesof the London Missionary Society)
consist of minutes of Board and Committee meetings,
copies of memorials from the Society to Governments,
Handwritten manuscript entitled "The story of William
Dampier". It contains details of Dampier's voyage from
1699 until 1702 to the west coast of Australia and
Batavia on the Roebuck, which was sunk near Ascen-
sion Island in 1702. MS 3475
reports, correspondence (official and personal), diaries
written by missionaries, and miscellaneous material.
They relate to the colonial countries of Africa, Asia and
Australia and include records of the Society in Mauritius
(1813-1848), Madagascar (1774-1899) and Travancore
and Ceylon (1817-1899). Microfiche: original records
are housed in the Library of the School of Oriental and
African Studies, London. MS In Process

5406 DALRYMPLE, Alexander
Papers, 1784-1806
4 cm
[sic] during a return voyage from London to Adelaide
and Point de Galle, Colombo in 1858-59.
MS 4003 NK 7160
Alexander Dalrymple was Hydrographer to the East
India Company (1779-95) and to the Admiralty (1795-
1808) and lived for many years in India. His papers
consist of 24 letters, memoranda and drafts written be-
tween 1784 and 1806. Many were those of Dalrymple to
Robert Saunders Dundas, 2nd Viscount Melville, con-
cerning Indian affairs including his request for an Ap-
pointment as Governor of Madras (1792) and a draft
entitled "Desultory thoughts on the British government
in India” (1802). Only one item relates to the Indian
Ocean: a memorandum by Dalrymple to Lord Mulgrave
5401 CLUNIES-ROSS, John
Papers
69p.
Papers written by John Clunies-Ross (1786-1854) relat-
ing to the Cocos Islands: a description of the islands,
remarks on Charles Darwin's theory of their coral for-
mation and an explanation of the oceanic tidal motions.
MS 2604
5402 COEDES, George
Papers, 1902-68
36 cm
dated 1787. It documentsthe discovery and later history
of Diego Garcia, a coral atoll in Chagos Archipelago. He
relates that the island was "unquestionably discovered
by the Portuguese thou in what year or by whom is
unknown". In 1745-46 the island was visited by the
Pelham, and in 1763 by the Pitt. The commander of the
Pitt, Captain Joseph Jackson "made a plan" of the is-
land. In 1774 Captain Adam Sheriff was sent from Bom-
bay to survey the island, and on behalf of the East India
Company landed sheep, pigs and goats. In 1778 M,
Dupuit de la Faye "got agreement of this island from the
government of Mauritius to establish a fishery" but
withdrew later, leaving only a few officers. The English
in 1786, "not knowing that the French had people there
determined to settle the island and use it as a port to
take on fresh water and supplies during their voyages to
India". MS 43
In 1970 the National Library purchased through Drijver
and Koolemans of Amsterdam the collection of Profes-
sor George Coedes (1886-1970), a former Director of
L'Ecole franpaise d'Extrbme Orient. He had spent 35
years in French Indo-China. There are approximately
36 cm of papers and typescripts in the Cobdes manus-
cript collection. They include a guide to source material
related to the Indian Ocean published in the Bulletin of
the Indian Ocean International Historical Association,
Saint Denis, La Reunion Jan. 1963; 1-24, MS 2986
5403 CONVICT DOCUMENTS, 1842
1 Leaf
List of prisoners tried at Port Louis Mauritius, 26 Oc-
tober 1842, and sentenced to transportation. MS 3279


DARWIN, Charles
Diary and notebooks, 1831-36
2 reels positive microfilm
Diary and notebooks kept by Darwin during his voyage
around the world in the Beagle (1831-36). He visited
Cocos Islands and Mauritius in 1836, and histheories on
coral reef formation were based on observations he
made on this voyage. Darwin's diary and notebooks are
located in Downe House, Kent, England. GlO, 315-16
DE MANTYN
Journal, 1773-74
1 vol.
Journal written in French by De Mantyn who was an
officer on board L'Oiseau which accompanied Le Ro-
land and La Dauphine on Yves de Kerguelen's second
voyage from October 1773 until March 1774. It was
during this voyage that Kerguelen realised that the
small islands which now bear his name were not part of
the great south land, as he had believed when he disco-
vered them the previous year, 1772. In his disappoint-
ment he named them the Land of Desolation. [1 reel
positive microfilm also held G3706] M 54275 NK 10396
DU BATY, R. Rallier, Capt.
Papers, 1907-14
Collection of papers concerning the voyage of the
French navigator and explorer R. Rallier Du Baty to the
Kerguelen Islands in 1907 and 1908 in the ship La
Curieuse. It contains hydrographical and geological
notes on the Kerguelen Islands, a map of Amsterdam
Island, a typescript manuscript entitled "Les Isles St
Paul and Amsterdam" and "Mission de L'lsle Saint-
Paul: mbtborologie" and an agreement between Du
Baty and th e Daily Chronicle (London) for the sale of the
story of his voyage (1910). MS 5403
DUNBABIN, Thomas
Report, 1955
21 p.

American-Australian relations between 1792 and 1812
dealing with the presence of American whaling ships in
Australian waters, and the location of these records in

HELOUIS, Madame Robert
Transcriptions, 1912
In 1912 Professor Ernest Scott arranged, on behalf of the
Australian government, for Madame Hdlouis to trans-
cribe from the archives of the Ministry of Marine, Paris,
and the Museum of Natural History, Le Havre, docu-
ments relating to Australia, They include papers con-
cerning Yves de Kerguelen and Franpois de St Al-
louarn's voyages (1771-74), Nicolas Baudin's voyages
(1800-04) and Matthew Flinder's detention on the lie de
France (1803-10). A detailed list is available on the con-
tent of the transcriptions. A brief description follows:
Folders
1-18 Journals kept by St Allouarri (1772) and Baudin,
Victor Couture, Giraud, Jaques Hamelin, Jaques
de Saint Cricq and Franpois Ronsard during the
voyages of the Gbographe and the Naturalists
(1800-04).
19 Baudin expedition: Papers, charts, plans and
despatches written by the Minister of Marine,
Paris and Baudin relating to the expedition to
explore the coasts of Australia. It also contains
Pierre Milius' report after he took command of
the Gdographe following Baudin's death in
1803,
20 French exploration before La Perouse: A trans-
lation of the log of Vlaming's voyage to Amster-
dam Island and Australia's west coast (Swan
River) 1696-97. Report on the west coast of Aus-
tralia, Rottnest Island and Gbographe Bay.
22-24 Voyages of Yves de Kerguelen and Francois
de St AUouarn (1771-74). Papers relating to
their voyages include accounts of voyages,
despatches and instructions concerning their
finances and management.
25-26 Miscellaneous papers: Reports by Franpois
Hierisson on the Swan River; Louis Freycinet,
Pierre Faure and Franpois Hierisson on Dirk Har-
tog's island; Stanislas Levillain on the zoology of
Rottnest Island and the Swan River; Joseph
Ransonnett on King George's Sound; Mont-
bazin de Bonnefoi on the coast of south west
Australia to the north of the Archipelago of the
islands of St Pierre and St Franpois.
29 De Caen papers: Letters written from Matthew
Flinders to Charles de Caen relating to the
seizure of Flinders ship Cumberland and his de-
tention on the lie de France from 1803 until
1810. MS 11
5412 INTERNATIONAL MISSIONARY COUNCIL and CON-
FERENCE OF BRITISH MISSIONARY SOCIETIES
Records, 1910-1945
31 metres
The joint archives of the International Missionary Coun-
cil and the Conference of British Missionary Societies
relating to India and Africa cover the period from the
World Missionary Conference held at Edinburg in 1910,
to 1945. The records relate chiefly to India and to British
Africa; but there is also much important material on
areas under Belgian, Portuguese and French control
and relating to educational policy, the Indian indepen-
dence movement and early development of the Na-
tional Christian Councils. The material consists of cor-
respondence and memoranda relating to J.H. Oldham
and W. Paton, together with rare printed material. The
records are on microfiche. MS In Process
5413 JORNDALE, E.
Journal, 1897-98
1 vol.
Journal kept by Jorndale on board the brig Edward
during a voyage to the Kerguelen Islands to research
aquatic fauna, in 1897 and 1898, MS 298
5414 KING, Phillip Parker
Journal and log, 1821-22
1 reel positive microfilm
Naval officer, hydrographer and son of Governor Philip
Gidley King, Philip Parker King sailed in the Bathurst in
1821 from Sydney by way of Torres Strait to the north
west coast of Australia. After a visit to Mauritius he
resumed the survey of the west coast, and arrived back
in Sydney in November 1822. Copied from the original
in the Library of the Admiralty, London (MS 738).
5415 MILIUS, Pierre Bernard
Journal, 1800-04
258 p.
A journal written in French entitled "Voyage aux Terres
Australes (1800-04)". Milius joined the Naturaiiste as
part of Nicolas Baudin's expedition to explore the
coasts of Australia and this narrative records his voyage
to the He de France, then to the west coast of Australia
and Sydney, his journey to China on th e Arthur and his
return to the Me de France on the Diane in 1803, where he
was appointed to command the Gbographe after
Baudin's death in September 1803. A short version of
this narrative of Milius' voyage to China and thence to
the Me de France was published in Annales Maritimes,
1817: 673-700 and 1818: 349-61. Photostat copy: the


original manuscript is in the possession of Mr Shand
Kydd of "Kooringa" Milong via Young, N.S.W. 2594,
1966.
2 reels positive microfilm also held G 7755-56. MS 1787
NORCOCK, Charles James
Journals and log book, 1863-75
5 vols.
Charles Norcock (later Vice-Admiral) kept four private
journals and a semi-official log book during his voyage
to Africa, Australia, India, China and New Zealand as a
midshipman and later a Lieutenant on HMS Blanche,
Phoebe and Iron Duke and on the P and 0 steamer
Malacca. Norcock described and logged the Blanche's
voyage in 1868 through the Indian Ocean from Cape
Town to St George's Sound, Western Australia. In 1871
he wrote fourteen pages in his journal during a month's
voyage in the Malacca from St George's Sound to Galle,
Ceylon where the ship berthed, then to Bombay, before
sailing for England through the Suez Canal,
2 reels positive microfilm also held G 21,336-7. MS 5897
NORCOCK, John Henry
Journal, 1835-37
Private journal kept by Norcock from 1835 until 1837. It
gives an account of his voyage in HMS Rattlesnake from
Bombay to Sydney by way of Mauritius, his periods
ashore in Bombay, Port Louis and Sydney, and his re-
turn voyage to England on the barque Kinnear.
1 reel positive microfilm also held G2l, 335. MS 5896
PELSAERT, Francois
Report, 1647
106 leaves
Report written by Pelsaert in 1647 entitled "Disastrous
voyage of the vessel Batavia to the East Indies in 1628
and 1629." The Batavia commanded by Pelsaert was
wrecked in 1629 on a coral reef off the west coast of
Australia. Typescript copy and translation, MS 117
PETHERICK, Edward A.
Papers, 1756-1917
2.72 metres
Petherick was a bibliographer and collector. His valu-
able collection of Australiana was acquired by the Aus-
tralian Government in 1909. Amongst his collection of
manuscripts are two series which contain papers relat-
ing to exploration in the Indian Ocean and Australasia.
Series 10 "European enterprise in Australasia". These
papers relate to a series of articles entitled "European
enterprise in Australia" written by Petherick in 1883 and
1884. He described them as "sketches written at the
suggestion of Henry Gyles Turner editor of The Mel-
bourne Review, which link the work of the explorers
with current European history and show what led to
the discoveries in Australasia. I had only completed the
Portuguese and Spanish enterprises and was about to
begin those of the Dutch when the publication of the
Review was suspended." (32 cm)
Series 12, Discovery of Australia. This series contains
papers assembled by Petherick during his research into
the alleged discovery of Australia by a Florentine,
Amerigo Vespucci in 1499. His conclusions were pre-
sented to the Royal Geographic Society in 1897. MS 760
POWELL, Charles
Papers, 1907-51
2 cm
Papers relating to William Dampier including a type-
script manuscript entitled: "Life and adventures of Cap-
tain William Dampier" (1907) by Powell and annotated
by Leslie Marchant. Merchant's notes and list of the
contents of Powell's Dampier file located at his Somer-
set vicarage, are also included in this collection.
MS 1284

cois de St Allouarn's voyage in Le Gros Ventre in 1772
from Mauritius to the west coast of Australia where at
Shark Bay he took possession of the land for France. St
Allouarn then sailed up the coast to Timor. Positive
photostat MS 1722

TAYLOR, Sir Gordon
Papers, 1925-67
5 m. 28 cm
The collection contains 16 cm of papers relating to the
first flight across the Indian Ocean. Taylor made the
crossing in 1939 from Port Hedland, Western Australia
to Mombasa, East Africa by way of Cocos, Chagos and
Seychelles Islands in the flying boat Cuba and surveyed
the air-route for the British and Australian Govern-
ments. The papers consist of Taylor's correspondence
with the Australian and British Governments priorto the
flight, his contract, messages to and from the Guba
during the flight, congratulatory messages, financial
papers, his report of the survey (47p.) and an unpub-
lished manuscript entitled "The Indian Ocean story"
(88p.). MS 2594
WOLLASTON, John R.
Journal, 1840-41
Journal written by Wollaston during the voyage of his
family from England to Western Australia on the ship
Henry in 1840 and 1841. It contains a detailed descrip-
tion of Cape Town and the difficult weather conditions
prevailing in the Indian Ocean. Wollaston settled in Pt.
Leschenault (Bunbury). Typescript copy: original jour-
nal Is located at the Mitchell Library, Sydney. MS 104
Australian Joint Copying Project
The Project's areas of interest include the eastern por-
tion of the Indian Ocean, Indonesia, Malaysia and adja-
cent areas. Documents copied for the Project fall into
two groups the first group consists of official records
copied at the Public Record Office, London while the
second consists of records copied from private collec-
tions (the miscellaneous or M series).
Public Record Office records which contain material
of relevance to the Indian Ocean area and which have
been copied as part of the Australian Joint Copying
Project Include the following:
Colonial Office C.O. 537 which
includes despatches from the Straits Settlements and
from Ceylon, 1873-98, and C.O. 700 which includes
maps and plans of the Indian Ocean and the East Indies;
C.O. 18 Western Australia. Original correspondence,
1828-1900, from officials and private individuals con-
tains material relating to navigation and trade in the
Indian Ocean. (A detailed list of Colonial Office Confi-
dential Prints relating to Mauritius and Western Au-
stralia is in Section V).
Foreign Office records, especially F.O. 27 General cor-
respondence. France, 1782-1904 and F.O. 37 General
correspondence. Holland and Netherlands 1781-1905.
(For Foreign Office confidential prints dealing with the
Indian Ocean region see Section V).
Board of Trade records 1786-1863, containing refer-
ences to trade with Java.
Admiralty records, particularly Adm, 1, 1809-1900,
which includes Admirals' despatches from the East In-
dies; Adm. 51-56, which include masters' and captains'
logs of ships on voyages of exploration 1740-1861; and
Adm. 125 which contains correspondence from the East
Indies and the China Station, 1830-1900.
Selections from the Australian Joint Copying Project
follow this general entry.
BYRON, John, Vice-Admiral
Journal, 1764-66
1 reel positive microfilm
Journal kept by Byron during his period of command of
HMS Dolphin, which returned to England via Batavia
and the Cape of Good Hope. The original diary is held by
the National Maritime Museum, Greenwich, London,
England.
5427 COCHRANE, Sir Thomas John
Papers, 1842-49
23 reels positive microfilm
Cochrane, who reached the rank of admiral of the fleet
in the Royal Navy, was second in command of the East
India Station 1842-5 and Commander-in-Chief 1845-7.
The papers include letters about naval surveys in the
Mauritius area; Admiralty correspondence regarding
the Malay Archipelago; log books, registers and orders
for the East India Station 1842-7. The originals are held
in the National Library of Scotland, Edinburgh.
M 948-970
5428 COTTON, W.J.
Diary, 1874-76
1 reel positive microfilm
Diary kept by Cotton during a return voyage from Eng-
land to Australia between December 1874 and January
1876. He spent time in Galle, Ceylon and Mauritius dur-
ing his return to England via the Cape of Good Hope.
The original diary is in the possession of M.W. Gregory,
14 Southampton Road, Fareham, Hampshire, England.
5429 DANVERS, Frederick Charles
Transcripts of records, compiled in 1893-95 from origi-
nals dated 1600-1699
27 reels positive microfilm
Transcripts in Dutch, with some England translations, of
documents concerning Dutch activity in India and the
East Indies. The original transcripts, copied from mate-
rial held in the State Archives in The Hague, are held by
India Office Records. 197 Blackfriars Road, London.
M 550-576
5430 EAST INDIA COMPANY
Records, 1769-1830
66 reels of positive microfilm
In 1786 the British East India Company purchased from
the King of Quedah the island of Pulo Penang, which it
renamed Prince of Wales Island (now known as
Penang). In 1795 the Dutch surrendered Malacca and its
dependencies; it was briefly restored to the Dutch in
1818-25. In 1805 Penang was constituted a Presidency.
In 1819 the British Government was permitted to estab-
lish a factory at Singapore and in 1826 Penang, Singa-
pore and Malacca were Incorporated as the Straits Set-
tlements, the Governor being responsible to the
Governor-General in India.
Records copied comprise lengthy reports, letters and
despatches relating to the British East India Company's
interests in the Straits Settlements. The main body of
these factory records are consultations or proceedings
of the Presidents and Councils sent contemporaneously
to the Company in London. There are Bengal Consulta-
tions relating to Prince of Wales Island, 1786-95, Prince
of Wales Island Public Consultations, 1805-30, with in-
dexes, 1808-30, Prince of Wales Island Secret and Pol iti-
cal Consultations, 1806-11, 1813, 1818, 1826-29 with
indexes, Prince of Wales Military Consultations, 1806-7
with index, Singapore Political and Secret Consulta-
tions, 1827-28, with index, Malacca Public Consulta-
tions, 1827, and Malacca Political Consultations, 1828.
There are also letters and abstracts of letters from
Prince of Wales Island, 1805-30, and despatches and
their abstracts from the Company to the Prince of Wales
Island, 1805-30.
Other records have been grouped under the headings
Singapore diary 1827-30, with index, Malacca diary
1826-30, with index, and Malacca journal and ledger
1826-30. There are separate groups of miscellaneous
documents and reports 1769-95 and 1805-10. M 470-535


5431 FLINDERS, Matthew
Papers, 1801-12
1 reel positive microfilm
From 1803 to 1810 Flinders was a prisoner of the French,
on Mauritius, and correspondence written by him to the
British Admiralty during his imprisonment has been
selected from Public Record Office classes Admiralty 1
and Admiralty 7. M 444
5432 FROME, Edward Charles
Sketchbooks, 1835-53
1 reel of negative microfilm, plus 164 colour trans-
parencies and 164 black and white photographic prints
A soldier and surveyor, Frome served with the Royal
Engineers in Mauritius following a term as Surveyor-
General of South Australia 1839-49.
The majority of the items in the sketchbooks are water-
colours of South Australian scenes, but sketch book 4
contains nine watercolours of scenes painted ca. 1852
and 1853 when Frome was stationed in Mauritius. The
watercolours depict the following; Pieter Both, Creve
Coeur pass. Port Louis mountains "from site of prop-
osed lighthouse on the reef beyond Cannonier Point,
1853," Tamarin falls area, islands north of Mauritius and
wreck of the Sydney near Cannoniers Point, and
Malabar 1852.
The Frome collection was copied for the Australian
Joint Copying Project when it was held by the Royal
Commonwealth Society, London, but the collection is
now located in the Art Gallery of South Australia, North
Terrace, Adelaide. M 987
5433 GREAT BRITAIN. Colonial Office.
Records relating to the Malay states, 1873-96
13 reels positive microfilm
Extracts relating to the protected Malay states, copied
from the Public Record Office classes C O. 273, C.O. 537
and C.O. 809. They include confidential and open de-
spatches from the Governor of the Straits Settlements,
Colonial Office minutes and draft replies, and miscel-
laneous correspondence from individuals and non-
official organizations. M 446-458
5434 PETWORTH HOUSE Archives

lished Ist July 1773. The original is at Petworth House,
Petworth, West Sussexx, England. M 823
5435 SCHOOL OF ORIENTAL AND AFRICAN STUDIES
Collections, 1769-1960
6 reels of positive microfilm
The collections include a volume of Malay and Sumat-
ran manuscripts of the 18th century, vocabularies com-
piled by Sir Joseph Banks during Captain James Cook's
first voyage 1768-71, including one relating to
Madagascar. The originals are located in the School of
Oriental and African Studies, Malet Street, London, Eng-
land. M 681-686
5436 WILTSHIRE RECORD OFFICE
Collections, 1787-1872
1 reel positive microfilm
Among the collections filmed at the Wiltshire Record
Office are the John Palmer papers, which include cor-
respondence 1823-29 dealing with commercial and
political activities in Java, and the Thomas E. Bate let-
ters written in 1871 and 1872 during his period of service
in the Far East aboard H.M.S. Iron Duke, M 935
5437 MAURITIUS Collection
Papers, 1737-1963
64cm
A collection of manuscripts relating to Mauritius. It
formed part of a large collection of books, pamphlets,
manuscripts, maps and drawings which was purchased
by the National Library in 1968 from the widow of Andre
de Chapuiset le Merle of Mauritius. The items are ar-
ranged as far as possible in chronological order.
MS 2282
5438 Mahb de la Bourdonnais, Bertrand Franpois. Five orders
to pay and receipts, 1737-43. La Bourdonnais (1699-
1753) was governor of Mauritius 1735-46 and greatly
influenced its development.
5439 La Caille, Abbb de. "Operations gbombtriques et
trigonombtriques faites dans Tile de France." 1753. This
forty-page manuscript and other works by La Caille
were used as reference works by later scholars of
Mauritius.
5440 Pingrb, Alexandre, Pare. Letter and note 1760 from
Pingrb, an astronomer, concerning preparations for his
expedition to Mauritius to observe the planet Venus;
extracts concerning his stay in Rodrigues and
Mauritius, May-September 1761.
5441 Two documents 1762, transferring to the Hdtel des In-
valides two soldiers stationed on Mauritius.
5442 Montlezun, Franpoise-Charlotte, Marquise de. Letters
and notes 1766-91 including notes on the history of the
families of Mahb de La Bourdonnais and Montlezun.
The Marquise was the daughter of Bertrand Franpois de
Mahb de La Bourdonnais.
5443 "Recensement de la population a Tile de France 28
November 1776." This typescript bears a pencilled note
"comp. Guy Rouillard." It consists of a ninety-one page
detailed list, in alphabetical order by surname, of the
inhabitants of Mauritius at 28 November 1776, showing
for each individual occupation, age, birthplace, date of
arrival, and current abode. A twenty-two page appendix
is an alphabetical index of ships mentioned in the cen-
sus, showing date of voyage.
5444 Lerot, Louis Franpois "Mbmoire ou essay tendant b db-
montrer la nbcessitb du retablissement de la Compag-
nie des Indes, avec tousles droits de souverainetb au-
tant pour la conservation du commerce au delb du Cap
de Bonne Esperance que pour les avantages des Fi-
nances de TEtat, et ceux des armateurs particuliers du
Royame. Dbdib b la mbmoire du cblbbre La Bourdon-
nais." 1784, 95 pages. Lerot was a former officer of the
Compagnie des Indes (the French East Indian Com-
pany).
5445 Charpentier de Cossigny, D. Letterbook: internal cor-
respondence August 1790-June 1792. Cossigny was
administrator of the Mascarene Islands during this
period, and the letterbook contains copies of letters
written by him in his official capacity, many of them
dealing with defence matters.
5446 L'Echelle, Louis. Order to pay, 1793.
5447 Modeste. "Journal de navigation, Juin 1794." This item
is a fragment consisting of one leaf, dated 19-20 June
1794, describing a battle with Dutch ships. It includes a
note to the effect that it was written by a Lieutenant
Bonamy aboard the corsair Modeste.
5448 "Recueil contenant huit copies de manuscrits inbdits
sur Tile de Madagascar" (c. 1809-c. 1820).
Includes the following papers:
(1) Extrait du Journal d'un voyage fait b Madagascar en
1809 sur la geolette YUranie par M. Mellar. 15 pages.


(2) Sur une coutume de Madagascar dont parle
Flacourt, par M.E.G., membra de la Socibtb d'Emu-
lation de I'lle de France (c. 1809). 16 pages. Pub-
lished mAnnaies des voyages, vol. 14, page 304 t
(1811).
(3) Apercu demon voyage a Ancove en avril et mai
1808 (by N. Mayeur?). 60 pages.
(4) Extrait des considerations sur I'tle de Madagascar.
60 pages.
(5) Lettre de Thompson (?) a Telfair, datde de
Tamatave, 12 mai 1814. 50 pages.
(6) Notes sur des graines diverses provenant de
Madagascar.
(7) Introduction of the alphabet (into Madagascar) (in
English). 124 pages. An analysis of and commentary
on "the Jahwee characters" or Malay language,
with examples of vocabulary and grammatical
forms.
Kent. Ship's journal 17 February-23 June 1800. The
Kent, an East Indiaman of 1200 tons, with 38 guns,
sailed from England in April 1800, bound for Bengal. An
entry showing simply "1800, 7 Octobre" is accom-
panied by a clipping (of later date) stating that the Kent,
an English vessel, was seized by Robert Surcouf leading
a mere handful of men. Surcouf, a famous corsair, was
in command of the French privateer Confiance in 1811.
De Caen, C.M.1., General. Legal document nominating
as judge M. Morin, signed at I'lle de France, 6 March
1807.
"Account of the conquest of Mauritius with some
notices on the history, soil, products, defences, and the
political importance of this island, to which is added a
sketch and map explanatory of the military operations:
by an officer who served on the expedition." Bound
transcript, 70 pages, of the book published in London,
1811, for T. Egerton, Military Library, Whitehall. The
final eight pages contain the terms of capitulation of
Mauritius to the British.
Froberville, Barthelemy Huet de. 303 page volume of
poetry, 1801-1832, including "La Ruspa ide ou Les in-
comparables fails et gestes de Frbre Jdrome dit Ruspa,"
p. 146-236, a satirical poem written in 1832 whose sub-
ject is Reverend Edward Slater, a priest on Mauritius.
Leven. Journal 15 July-19 August 1824 (in French) of a
voyage in the British ship Leven, captain W.F.W. Owen,
The writer (unnamed) was employed as a botanist on
the Leven, collecting specimens, mainly from
Madagascar, for the Royal Horticultural Society in Lon-
don.
Register of tombs of the cemetery at Port Louis,
Mauritius, 1825-1841, consisting of two volumes, being
account books kept to record payment of the tax intro-
duced in October 1825 on the erection of tombstones.
The first book contains a schedule of rates to be paid
and balance sheets 1825-1838, with register of
tombstones erected 17 November 1837 to 23 August
1841, showing date, name of deceased, person paying
the levy, and amount paid. The second book contains
the register from 1 November 1825 to 15 November
1837.
Legal document, signed at Port Louis, Mauritius on 15
December 1829, appointing Sir Robert Farquhar as at-
torney and London representative of twenty-three mer-
chants and residents of Mauritius. He was to act on their
behalf in prosecuting for libel those connected with the
publication of "A picture of the Negro slavery existing in
the Mauritius" in The Anti-Slavery Reporter, no. 44,
1829.
Dupont, Evenor, Letters 1829-39 written mainly from
London, from Adrien d'Epinay, Prosper d'Epinay and
Herman Geffroy, concerning the abolition of slavery
and political events affecting Mauritius.
5457 Kelsey, T.S. Four letters 1846, exchanged between
Kelsey and Lord Grey, the Secretary of State for the
Colonies, concerning Kelsey's salary and request for
leave of absence from his post of Receiver of Registra-
tion Dues, Mauritius.
5458 Circular 1851 in English, from Procureur and Advocate
General’s Chambers requesting returns of marriages
celebrated between Indians and Creole women, and
Indians and Indian women.
5459 A copy of Lord Campbell's Act, to amend the Law of
Evidence, 7 August 1851.
5460 Bonnefoy, T. Manuscript (ca. 500 pages) for a book,
entitled "Table gdndrale des lois transcrites ou de-
posdes au greffe de la cour d'appel de I'tle Maurice,
ci-devant He de France, 1853." A preamble summarises
administrative changes 1722-1843, the period covered
by the book. The manuscript is in the form of an al-
phabetic subject index, giving under each subject the
title of the act, with date, date of regulations, and name
of administration during which the act was passed.
Bonnefoy was at one time archivist to the cour d'appel.
5461 Stevenson, Sir William, governor of Mauritius. Nine
memoranda 1857-59 written in English by Stevenson to
government officials relating to auditing and treasury
affairs.
5462 Dumat, Pere.
(i) Five letters and notes, 1863, including one of eleven
pages, written between Dumat and Bridet, captain
of the port of Bourbon, Reunion. These papers dis-
cuss the provenance of articles, such as cannon,
salvaged from the He aux Sables, and voyages and
shipwrecks in the area, especially ca. 1818.
(ii) Draft unsigned letter in French 28 September 1849,
prepared by Dumat, accompanied by an English
version dated 26 October 1849 and signed by
Dumat. The letters request the governor of
Mauritius, Sir W. Anderson, to consider a plan out-
lined in the letters for supplying the Seychelles is-
lands with Indian immigrant labour. Dumat was a
landholder in the Seychelles.
5463 "Mfitoorologie, faits divers, extraits, et dvbnements re-
marquables ayant eu lieu A I'lle Maurice depuis 1709 A
1869 ..." Sixty-page book containing clippings from
newspapers and other printed sources, concerning
Mauritius and the nearby islands; biographical note on
Bridet, director of the Saint-Denis observatory 1851.
5464 Withers, James. Letter 10 September 1878 from the
Colonial Secretary to Withers, concerning a contract.
5465 Osughr ue, Fran,coise. Share certificate 1879 in the
Credit Agricole et Commercial, Mauritius.
5466 Margry, G. Two personal letters 1882-3, the first from
Julien Vinson, the second from Vice-Admiral E. Jurien.
5467 Connal, Michel, Surveyor-General of Mauritius. Report,
with covering letter 26 October 1883, entitled "Water for
household purposes."
5468 Royal Society of Arts and Sciences of Mauritius. Bronze
medal certificate 1884
5469 Noel, M. "Mdmoire sur la situation des intdr§ts religieux
A Tile Maurice, presents A son Eminence le Cardinal
Prqfet de la Propaganda par I'Union Catholique de cette
He," Seventeen-page memorandum dated 1 March
1885 dealing with topics such as Church-State relations,
education, and the role of the laity.
5470 Newton, Sir William (fl, 1850-1916). Twelve letters
1881-1916 received by Newton, Kings Counsel and
Member of the Mauritius Council. He was a delegate for
Mauritius in London in the latter part of the nineteenth
century, but lived at various times on Mauritius. His
correspondents include Sultan Abdullah of Perak in the


Seychelles, G.H. Griffiths, Maurice Bouchas, C. Baissac
and George Guibert. Some of the letters relate to official
and political matters such as the Pope-Hennessy con-
troversy and administration of the Seychelles by G.H.
Griffiths, while others are personal.
5471 Laval, E. Circular letter, in French, dated 3 June 1897,
seeking assistance for proposed celebrations in
Mauritius for Queen Victoria's Jubilee.
5472 Pope-Hennessy, Sir John (1834-1891), governor of
Mauritius 1883-89. Letter 8 March 1887 introducing Al-
phonse Gaud, his private secretary, to the Bishop of
Madagascar.
5473 Daruty de Grandprd, Emile. Eight letters 1890-1911,
written mainly by Albert Pitot, historian, editor and pub-
lisher, concerning literary and publishing matters; an
invitation to attend a function for the Duke and Duchess
of Cornwall and York, 1901.
5474 Boyer de la Giroday, Vincent. Descendance de Fran-
Coise Chatelain de Clorcy. Saint-Denis, Reunion,
Drouhet, n.d. 35 sheets. Genealogy of the descendants
of Franpoise Chatelain (1659-1730), member of a group
of fifteen girls sent from France in 1673 to be brides of
colonists on Bourbon. There is much material of Mauri-
tian interest in the extensive family tree, compiled bet-
ween 1930 and 1938.
5475 Gillet, Gabriel. Draft of a circular earlier 1908, in French,
written by Gillet, seeking support for the establishment
of a journal to publish literary and historical articles
relating to Mauritius.
5476 O'Connor, Owen L. Volume of press cuttings and notes
compiled by O'Connor in 1910 relating to Sir John
Pope-Hennessy (1834-91) and his period as Governor of
Mauritius, 1883-89.
5477 Three miscellaneous letters dated 1911, 1912and1949.
Addressees and writers not known, though the latter is
written by a cleric and mentions plans to go to Rome.
5478 Wilson, Frank. Typescript report by Wilson 1932 entitled
"Notes on cane planting" ca. 100 pages.
5479 Lorquet, P.W. Handwritten poem entitled "Les deux
Simone" signed, 1946. 69p.
5480 Ignace, Brother. An address broadcast by Brother Ig-
nace on 27 February 1948 on the occasion of the
seventy-fifth anniversary of the establishment of St
Joseph's College in Curepipe. Signed, typescript 7p.
5481 Heeringa, K. "De nederlanders op Mauritius en
Madagascar." Published in De Indische Gids, June
1895: 864-92 and July 1895: 1005-1036. French transla-
tion, 42p.
5482 Chapuiset le Merle, Andrd de. Mauritian bibliophile.
Family and general correspondence arranged in two
files; the family correspondence 1951-56 consists of
letters received by Le Merle together with copies of
some replies to his children Robert, Pierre, Ir6ne, Andrd
and Ellen (items 95-150). The general file (items 151-
193) contains letters 1912-1963, received by Le Merle.
Correspondents include Charles Maclean, Professor
P.A. Rdmy, Louis Baissac, Arthur Martial, Andrd Mas-
son, Edwin deßobilliard, P. deSornay, A.N.Sookia, R.G.
Vaughan. Matters dealt with include philately, historical
research, the Heeringa manuscript, erection of the 1598
monument, conservation of books and manuscripts,
and disposal of Le Merle's collection of books.
5483 Desvaux de Marigny. Two documents, one a sketch of
an armorial bearing labelled "Dumorier desvaux", the
other an authorisation (1819?) to Robert De Marigny by
the Royal Volunteers of Rouen, enabling him to wear
the "decoration du lys."
5484 Mahe. Genealogy of the Mahe family. Bertrand Francois
Mahd de la Bourdonnais (1694-1753) is included in the
pedigree.
5485 Gueuvin family. Photographs and incomplete small
family tree.
5486 Six small books containing press cuttings on the follow-
ing subjects: native unrest, cyclones, visitors to
Mauritius, the criminal Nanard who was executed in
1828, K. Hazareesingh's book A history of Indians in
Mauritius 1950,

DALRYMPLE, Alexander, 1737-1808.
Numerous charts relating to the coasts and islands of
Africa were published by Dalrymple, while he was Hyd-
rographer to the East India Company and later Director
of the Hydrographical Department of the Admiralty.
These charts appear in the following collections:
M 334. DALRYMPLE, Alexander. Dalrymple's charts [A collec-
tion in 3 vols. of charts, maps and plans for navigation]
vol. I: 1615-1806
vol. II: 1740-1806
vol. Ill: 1702-1807.
